## MATHEMATICS

9709/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 310, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 303, 910, 319]]<|/det|>

You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 419, 225, 435]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = \frac{4}{(x - 3)^3}\) for \(x > 3\). The curve passes through the point (4, 5).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 364, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The coefficient of \(x^{4}\) in the expansion of \((x + a)^{6}\) is \(p\) and the coefficient of \(x^{2}\) in the expansion of \((ax + 3)^{4}\) is \(q\). It is given that \(p + q = 276\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 455, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the possible values of the constant \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Express \(4x^{2} - 24x + p\) in the form \(a(x + b)^{2} + c\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers and \(c\) is to be given in terms of the constant \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 528, 186, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 526, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
Hence or otherwise find the set of values of \(p\) for which the equation \(4x^{2} - 24x + p = 0\) has no real roots.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 543, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 87, 779, 293]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 317, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = 10x^{\frac{1}{2}} - \frac{5}{2} x^{\frac{3}{2}}\) for \(x > 0\). The curve meets the \(x\)-axis at the points (0, 0) and (4, 0).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 365, 396, 384]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 367, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[326, 87, 707, 237]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 259, 920, 280]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sector \(OAB\) of a circle with centre \(O\). Angle \(AOB = \theta\) radians and \(OP = AP = x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 291, 148, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 291, 485, 310]]<|/det|>
Show that the arc length \(AB\) is \(2x\theta \cos \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 291, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 146, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 500, 633, 518]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region \(APB\) in terms of \(x\) and \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 500, 920, 518]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 148, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 688, 106]]<|/det|>
Prove the identity \(\frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta + \sin \theta} + \frac{1 - \cos \theta}{\cos \theta - \sin \theta} \equiv \frac{\cos \theta + \sin \theta - 1}{1 - 2 \sin^2 \theta}.\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 78, 920, 97]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 525, 186, 544]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 524, 586, 546]]<|/det|>
Using the results of (a)(ii) and (b), solve the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[298, 549, 700, 586]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\sin \theta}{\cos \theta + \sin \theta} +\frac{1 - \cos \theta}{\cos \theta - \sin \theta} = 2(\cos \theta + \sin \theta - 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 590, 268, 609]]<|/det|>
for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 590, 920, 609]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 92, 910, 352]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 373, 915, 393]]<|/det|>
The diagram above shows part of the graph of the function \(\mathrm{g}(x) = 3 + 2\sin \frac{1}{4} x\) for \(-2\pi \leqslant x \leqslant 2\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 406, 920, 441]]<|/det|>
Complete the sketch of the graph of \(\mathrm{g}(x)\) on the diagram above and hence explain whether the function \(\mathrm{g}\) has an inverse. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 565, 148, 584]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 565, 920, 618]]<|/det|>
Describe fully a sequence of three transformations which can be combined to transform the graph of \(y = \sin x\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\) to the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\), making clear the order in which the transformations are applied. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 755, 92]]<|/det|>
The second term of a geometric progression is 16 and the sum to infinity is 100.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 106, 519, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the two possible values of the first term.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Show that the \(n\)th term of one of the two possible geometric progressions is equal to \(4^{n - 2}\) multiplied by the \(n\)th term of the other geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 631, 92]]<|/det|>
For \(a = 4\), find the equation of the normal to the circle at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 448, 186, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 448, 920, 481]]<|/det|>
For \(a = 4\), find the equations of the two tangents to the circle which are parallel to the normal found in (b).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 460, 920, 480]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 329, 92]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 92, 584, 112]]<|/det|>
\[y = k\sqrt{4x + 1} -x + 5,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 117, 361, 135]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 153, 146, 172]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 149, 235, 173]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 155, 920, 173]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 500, 186, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 500, 621, 520]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of the stationary point in terms of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 502, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Given that \(k = 10.5\), find the equation of the normal to the curve at the point where the tangent to the curve makes an angle of \(\tan^{-1}(2)\) with the positive \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
